sections.Introduction:
The Harvard referencing style is commonly used in universities around the world. There are many different versions.

The version used at the University of Adelaide is referred to as Harvard UofA.
It is based on the Style manual for authors, editors and printers 2002, 6th ed., John Wiley & Sons, Milton, Qld.

This guide is a GUIDE ONLY – you may need to confirm specific referencing requirements for assignments with your lecturer or tutor.

Harvard is an author-date style.

When you refer to someone else’s work, you need to include a reference to that work in two places:

1. In-text: this is a short reference in your document, generally at the end of the relevant sentence or paragraph. It consists of the author’s family name, the year of publication and the page number for direct quotes (and where possible for other citations) inside a pair of brackets.

2. In the reference list: this is a complete list, in alphabetical order by author, of all the works you referenced in-text. The references give full details of each source..
sections.General Example:
Reference list

In your reference list, you usually include, in this order:

  • Author’s family name
  • Author’s initial(s)
  • Year of publication
  • Title of article or book, etc.
  • Publication details (journal information, publisher information)
  • Page numbers (if needed)

Here is a generic example for a journal article with three authors:

Author, AA, Author, B & Author, C Year, 'Article title in between single quotes, in lower case and with no full stop to end', ˰Journal Title in Italics with Capitals, vol. ##, no. #, pp. ##-##.

In-text reference

Give the author’s family name, followed by the year of publication. Enclose them in brackets at the end of your sentence. Include a page number where possible, especially if you are quoting directly from a source.

An in-text reference looks like this:
It has been claimed that... (Author Year, p. #).

It could also look like this:
Author claims that.... (Year, p. #).

sections.How do I reference one source mentioned:
If you want to reference the ideas of Author A that are included in the work of a second author (Author B), but you have not read Author A's original work, this is an indirect citation or secondary source.

In these cases:

  • Include the Author A and Author B information in the in -text reference, using "in" after Author A.

Example

Smith 2001 in Wright 2004

  • Your reference list should only include the source you actually viewed.

Wright, IM 2004, How to quote, Book Press, Adelaide.
sections.How do I reference multiple sources at o:
If you want to reference multiple sources at the same place in the text:

  • Put the in-text references in brackets in alphabetical order, separated by a semicolon.

Example

(Brown 2003; Miller 2009; Smith 2001).
sections.How do I reference different authors wit:
For two authors with the same family name, include their initials in the in-text reference. 

Examples

(E Peters 2007)

(P Peters 2009)

Reference list:

  • Give complete reference details as usual in the reference list
  • List them alphabetically in order of the family name followed by the authors’ initials.
sections.How do I reference multiple works by the: Two books or articles written in the same year – use the letters ‘a’ and ‘b’ in the text and in the reference list. e.g. Smith 2000a, Smith 2000b.
sections.How do I reference sources with no date:
If there is no date available, write n.d. after the author's family name.

If there is no author information, go to the specific reference type in this guide for an example (e.g. Book, Web Page, Reference Work).
sections.How do I reference sources with more tha: For in-text references, use 'and' between names in the text and '&' between names in brackets. Use ‘&’ between authors’ names in the reference list. Use the name of the first author and then 'et al.' for 4 or more authors in in-text references. Give all the authors in the reference list entry.
sections.How do I reference sources with multiple:
Book with many places of publication – choose the first.

Book with no place of publication – write n.p.

Give any extra information needed to disambiguate (e.g. Cambridge, Mass. vs Cambridge, UK) or to clarify ( St. Lucia, Qld, rather than just St. Lucia).
sections.What's the difference between an author:
• An author is someone who has written a particular text, such as a book or journal article.
  • An editor is someone who has compiled a text, such as a dictionary, or a book to which several authors have contributed.
sections.Do I need to include page numbers?: Page numbers should be included wherever possible and applicable.  It is important to remember that you need to include a page number if you quote or paraphrase. If you are referring only to one page, use the abbreviation p. If you are referring to more than one page, use the abbreviation pp. For example, use (Jones 2010, p. 112) for referring to one page and use (Jones 2010, pp.112-113) when referring to more than one page.

sections.Print / from UofA database:
• Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) Year of publication, ‘Title in single quotes’, Journal Title in Italics, vol. ##, (volume number) no. #, (issue number) pp. #-# (page numbers the article covers).

Notes and exceptions

  • Applies to print articles and articles accessed from a Library database.
  • You do NOT need to include a URL or database name.

Example: in reference list

Habel, C 2009, 'Academic self-efficacy in ALL: capacity-building through self-belief', Journal of Academic Language and Learning, vol. 3, no. 2, pp. 94-104.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Habel 2009, p. #)
sections.From web (freely available from an e-jou:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) Year of publication, ‘Title in single quotes’, Journal Title in Italics, vol. ##, (volume number) no. #, (issue number), viewed Date Month Year, pp. #-# (page numbers the article covers), <URL address>.

Notes and exceptions

  • If NOT accessed via a Library database, include date viewed and URL.
  • If volume, issue, or page numbers are unavailable, you can leave them out.
  • If there is other relevant information (e.g. publication month, article number), you can include that instead.

Example: in reference list

Ticker, CS 2017, 'Music and the mind: music's healing powers', Musical Offerings, vol. 8, no. 1, article 1, viewed 21 May 2017,
<http://digitalcommons.cedarville.edu /cgi/viewcontent.cgi ?article=1064&context=musicalofferings>.

Example: in text

(Ticker 2017, p. #)
sections.With DOI (Digital Object Identifier):
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) year of publication, ‘Title in single quotes’, Journal Title in Italics, vol. ##, (volume number) no. #(issue number) pp. #-# (page numbers the article covers), DOI:number.

Notes and exceptions

  • DOIs are not generally required for Harvard styles. However, if your lecturer requires them, add them at the end of the reference.
  • If you include the DOI, you do not need the date viewed or the URL.

Example: in reference list

Jeeyoo, L, Ji-Eun, L, Yuri, K, Lee, J, Lee, J-E & Kim, Y 2017, 'Relationship between coffee consumption and stroke risk in Korean population: the Health Examinees (HEXA) study', Nutrition Journal, vol. 16, pp. 1-8, DOI:10.1186/s12937-017-0232-y.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Jeeyoo et al. 2017, p. #)
sections.In press / advance online publication:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) year of publication, ‘Title in single quotes’, Journal Title in Italics, vol. ##, (volume number) no. #, (issue number) pp. #-# (page numbers the article covers), in press / advance online publication, DOI:number / viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Notes and exceptions

  • "In press" and "advance online publication" usually refer to articles that have been accepted for publication but not yet "officially" published.
  • Give the journal information, then "in press" or "advance online publication".
  • Follow with DOI if available/required, or date viewed, <URL>.
  • If volume/issue/page number information isn't available, leave it out.

Example: in reference list

Muldoon, K, Towse, J, Simms, V, Perra, O, & Menzies, V 2012, ‘A longitudinal analysis of estimation, counting skills, and mathematical ability across the first school year’, Developmental Psychology, advance online publication, DOI:10.1037/a0028240.

Example: in text

(Muldoon 2012, p. #)
sections.Two authors:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) & Author's family name, Initial(s) year of publication, ‘Title in single quotes’, Journal Title in Italics, vol. ##, (volume number) no. #, (issue number) pp. #-# (page numbers the article covers).

Notes and exceptions

  • Leave the authors' names in the order they appear on the article.
  • Separate the authors' names with an ampersand (&).

Example: reference list

Darwin, A & Palmer, E 2009, 'Mentoring circles in higher education', Higher Education Research and Development, vol. 28, no. 2, pp. 125-136.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Darwin & Palmer 2009, p. #)
sections.Three authors:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s), Author's family name, Initial(s) & Author's family name, Initial(s) year of publication, ‘Title in single quotes’, Journal Title in Italics, vol. ##, (volume number) no. #, (issue number) pp. #-# (page numbers the article covers).

Notes and exceptions

  • Leave the authors' names in the order they appear on the article.
  • Use an ampersand (&) to separate the last two authors.

Example: reference list

Maier, H, Baron, J & McLaughlan, R 2007, 'Using online roleplay simulations for teaching sustainability principles to engineering students', International Journal of Engineering Education, vol. 23, no. 6, pp. 1162-1171.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Maier, Baron & McLaughlan 2007, p. #)
sections.Four or more authors:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s), Author's family name, Initial(s), Author's family name, Initial(s) & Author's family name, Initial(s) year of publication, ‘Title in single quotes’, Journal Title in Italics, vol. ##, (volume number) no. #, (issue number) pp. #-# (page numbers the article covers).

Notes and exceptions

  • Leave the authors' names in the order they appear on the article.
  • Use an ampersand (&) to separate the last two authors.
  • In the reference list, include all authors.
  • In the in text reference, include first author then et al.

Example: reference list

Grosso, G, Stepaniak, U, Micek, A, Stefler, D, Bobak, M & Pajak, A 2017, 'Coffee consumption and mortality in three Eastern European countries: results from the HAPIEE (Health, Alcohol and Psychosocial factors In Eastern Europe) study', Public Health Nutrition, vol. 20, no. 1, pp. 82-91.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Grosso et al. 2017, p. #)

sections.Print:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) Year of publication, Title (in italics), Publisher, Place of Publication.

Notes and exceptions

  • If a book has many places of publication – choose the first.
  • If a book has no place of publication – write n.p.
  • Give any extra information needed to disambiguate (e.g. Cambridge, Mass. vs Cambridge, UK) or to clarify (St. Lucia, Qld, rather than just St. Lucia).

Example: in reference list

Connell, R 2009, Gender, Polity Press, Cambridge, UK.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Connell 2009, p. #)
sections.E-Book (from UofA database):
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) Year of publication, Title (in italics), Publisher, Place of Publication.

Notes and exceptions

  • If no place of publication is available, only list the publisher.
  • If a DOI is available, and your lecturer requires it, include this at the end of the reference.
  • If page numbers are unavailable, you can leave them out.

Example: in reference list

White, MA, McCallum, F & Seldon, A 2020, Critical perspectives on teaching, learning and leadership: enhancing educational outcomes, Springer Singapore Pte. Limited, Singapore, DOI:10.1007/978-981-15-6667-7.

Example: in text

(White 2020, p. #)
sections.E-Book (from web):
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) year of publication, Title (in italics), Publisher, Place of Publication, DOI:number / viewed Date Month Year, <URL address>.

Notes and exceptions

  • If no place of publication is available, only list the publisher.
  • Include date viewed and URL.
  • If a DOI is available, you can give this instead of the date viewed and URL.
  • If page numbers are unavailable, you can leave them out.

Example: in reference list

de Grosbois, T 2015, Mass influence: the habits of the highly influential, Wildfire Workshops, viewed 21 May 2017, <http://www.massinfluencethebook.com >.

Example: in text

(de Grosbois 2015, p. #)
sections.Two or three authors:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s), Author’s family name, Initial(s), & Author’s family name, Initial(s) year of publication, Title (in italics), Publisher, Place of Publication.

Notes and exceptions

  • List all authors' names.
  • Leave the authors' names in the order they appear on the article.
  • Separate the last two authors' names with an ampersand (&).

Example: in reference list

Campbell, E, Fox, R & de Zwart, M 2010, Students’ guide to legal writing, law exams and self assessment, 3rd edn, Federation Press, Sydney.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Campbell, Fox & de Zwart 2010, p. #)
sections.Four or more authors:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s), Author’s family name, Initial(s), Author’s family name, Initial(s), & Author’s family name, Initial(s) year of publication, Title (in italics), Publisher, Place of Publication.

Notes and exceptions

  • Leave the authors' names in the order they appear on the title page.
  • Use an ampersand (&) to separate the last two authors.
  • In the reference list, include all authors.
  • In the in text reference, include first author then et al.

Example: in reference list

Henkin, RE, Bova, D, Dillehay, GL, Halama, JR, Karesh, SM, Wagner, RH & Zimmer, MZ 2006, Nuclear medicine, 2nd edn, Mosby Elsevier, Philadelphia.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Henkin et al. 2006, p. #)
sections.Book chapter in edited book:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) Year of publication, 'Chapter title in single quote marks', in Editor(s) Initial(s) Family Name (ed or eds), Title (in italics), Publisher, Place of Publication, pp. xx-xx.

Notes and exceptions

  • Give author and chapter information first, then editor(s), book title, and publication information.
  • Include chapter page numbers at the end of the reference.
  • For the in text reference, give the chapter author and date.

Example: in reference list

Warner, R 2010, 'Giving feedback on assignment writing to international students - the integration of voice and writing tools', in WM Chan, KN Chin, M Nagami & T Suthiwan (eds), Media in foreign language teaching and learning, De Gruyter, Boston, pp. 355-382.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Warner 2010, p. #)
sections.Book with an edition number:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) year of publication, Title (in italics), Xth edn, Publisher, Place of Publication.

Notes and exceptions

  • Add edition number and the abbreviation 'edn' after the book title.
  • If no edition number is given, you don't need to include it.

Example: in reference list

Carroll, AB 2012, Business & society: ethics, sustainability, and stakeholder management, 8th edn, South-Western Cengage Learning, Mason, Oklahoma.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Carroll 2012, p. #)
sections.Book with no author:
Required information and layout

Title (in italics) Year of publication, Publisher, Place of Publication.

Notes and exceptions

  • Use the title in place of the author name, for both reference list and in text.

Example: in reference list

Style manual for authors, editors and printers 2002, 6th edn, John Wiley & Sons, Milton, Qld.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Style manual for authors, editors and printers 2002, p. #)
sections.Book with a volume number:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) year of publication, Title of whole work(in italics) vol. #,Title of specific volume if applicable (in italics), Publisher, Place of Publication.

Example: in reference list

Cowie, AP, Mackin, R & McCaig, IR 1983, Oxford dictionary of current idiomatic English, vol. 2, Phrase, clause and sentence idioms, Oxford University Press, Oxford.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Cowie, Mackin & McCaig 1983, p. #)
sections.Written in a foreign language:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) year of publication, Title in italics (translated title in brackets and italics), Publisher, Place of Publication

Notes and exceptions

  • Give an English translation of the book title only.

Example: in reference list

Lemmens, M 1996, 'La grammaire dans les dictionnaires bilingues', in H Béjoint & P Thoiron (eds), Les dictionnaires bilingues (Bilingual dictionaries), Duculot s.a., Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium, pp. 71-102.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Lemmens 1996, p. #)
sections.Translated from a foreign language:
Required information and layout

Author's family name, Initial(s) Year of publication, Title in italics, trans. Translator's Initial(s) Family name, Publisher, Place of Publication.

Example: in reference list

Jansson, T 1948, Finn family Moomintroll, trans. E Portch, Puffin Books, London.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Jansson 1948, p. #)

sections.Conference paper published in edited boo:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) Year of publication, ‘Title of paper’, in Editor’s initial(s) Editor’s family name (ed.), Title of conference (in italics), Conference Organiser/Publisher, Place of Publication, pp. xxx–xxx.

Notes and exceptions

  • Give author and paper information, then editor and conference information.
  • If no editor information is given, you can leave it out (see example below).

Example: in reference list

Laptev, I, Marszałek, M, Schmid, C & Rozenfeld, B 2008, 'Learning realistic human actions from movies', in 26th IEEE conference on computer vision and pattern recognition, CVPR, IEEE Computer Society, Anchorage, USA.

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Laptev et al. 2005, p. #)
sections.Conference paper published online:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) Year of publication, ‘Title of paper’, in Editor’s initial(s) Editor’s family name (ed.), Title of conference (in italics), Conference Organiser/Publisher, Place of Publication, pp. xxx–xxx, viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Notes and exceptions

  • Give author and paper information, then editor and conference information.
  • If some information is unavailable (e.g. editors, page numbers), you can leave it out.
  • If page numbers are unavailable, you can leave them out.

Example: in reference list

Crisp, G, Hillier, M & Joarder, S 2010, ‘Assessing students in Second Life – some options’, in CH Steel, MJ Keppell, P Gerbic, & S Housego (eds), Proceedings of the 27th annual ASCILITE conference: curriculum, technology and transformation for an unknown future, Sydney, pp. 256–261, viewed 15 July 2011, <http://www.ascilite.org.au/ conferences/sydney10/ proceedings.htm>.

Example: in text

(Crisp, G, Hillier, M & Joarder, S 2010, p. #)
sections.Conference presentation (unpublished):
Required information and layout

Author's family name, Initial(s) Year of publication, 'Title of paper', paper / abstract presented at name of conference (italics), Place conference held, Date(s) Month conference held.

Notes and exceptions

  • If page numbers are unavailable, you can leave them out.

Example: in reference list

Butler, D 2009, 'Using video worked examples to enhance learning in a first year mathematics course', paper presented at 4th ERGA conference, University of Adelaide, 24-25 September.

Example: in text

(Butler 2009, p. #)

sections.Print:
Required information and layout

Author's family name, Initial(s) year, 'Title of article', Title of news or magazine site (in italics), date of publication OR volume and issue, p.#.

Example: in reference list

Robertson, D & Kyriacou, K 2010, 'Skating on thin ice', Advertiser, 20 November, p. 9.

Example: in text

  • Include page number(s) for direct quotes and paraphrases.

(Robertson & Kyriacou 2010, p. #)
sections.Online:
Required information and layout

Author's family name, Initial(s) Year, 'Title of article', Title of news or magazine site (in italics), date of publication OR volume and issue, p.# (if available), viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Notes and exceptions

  • If page numbers are unavailable, you can leave them out.

Example: in reference list

Banks, D 2010, 'Tweeting in court: Why reporters must be given guidelines’, The Guardian, 15 December, viewed 25 November 2015, <http://www.theguardian.com /law/2010/dec/15/ tweeting-court-reporters-julian-assange>.

Example: in text

(Banks 2010, p. #)
sections.No author:
Required information and layout

Publication Name Year, 'Title of article', Title of news or magazine site (in italics), date of publication OR volume and issue, p.# (if available), viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Notes and exceptions

  • Give the publication name in place of the author name.
  • For articles viewed online, include date viewed and URL.

Example: in reference list

Evening Express 2014, ‘Firearms officer drove at 60mph on wrong side of road in Aberdeen’, Evening Express, 22 May, p. 12, viewed 18 April 2017, <http://www.eveningexpress.co.uk /news/local/firearms-officer-drove- at-60mph-on-wrong-side-of-road-in-aberdeen-1.382464>.

Example: in text

  • Include page number(s) for direct quotes and paraphrases.

(Evening Express 2014, p. #)

sections.With DOI:
Required information and layout

Author's family name, Initial(s) OR Authoring body year, Title of dataset (in italics), Physical location (if applicable), DOI.

Notes and exceptions

  • If available, include a reference point (for example: figure number or table number) in the in-text reference for the dataset.
  • The word figure can be abbreviated to fig.
  • If there is no author name, use the authoring body (e.g. company or department) instead.

Example: in reference list

U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, Office of Applied Studies 2013, Treatment episode data set -- discharges (TEDS-D) -- concatenated, 2006 to 2009, DOI:10.3886/ICPSR30122.v2.

Example: in text

(U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, Office of Applied Studies 2013)
sections.No DOI:
Required information and layout

Author's family name, Initial(s) OR Authoring body year, Title of dataset (in italics), Physical location (if applicable), viewed Date Month Year, <URL>

Notes and exceptions

  • If available, include a reference point (for example: figure number or table number) in the in-text reference for the dataset.
  • The word figure can be abbreviated to fig.
  • If there is no author name, use the authoring body (e.g. company or department) instead.

Example: in reference list

Bureau of Meteorology 2011, High-quality Australian daily rainfall dataset, Bureau of Meteorology, viewed 17 November 2011, <ftp://ftp.bom.gov.au/anon/home/ ncc/www/change/HQdailyR >

Example: in text

(Bureau of Meteorology 2011)

sections.Webpage:
Required information and layout

Author's family name, Initial(s) OR Authoring body Year, Title of webpage (in italics), Title of website, viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Notes and exceptions

  • Where possible, reference the specific page or section (not the whole website).
  • If there is no individual author name, use the authoring body name (company or organization - see example below).
  • If the website document doesn't have an individal OR corporate author, use the document title followed by the year.
  • If there is no year, use n.d.

Example: in reference list

World Health Organization 2014, WHO recommendations for routine immunization – summary tables, World Health Organization, viewed 1 May 2014, <http://www.who.int/immunization/ policy/ummunization_tables /en/>.

Example: in text

(World Health Organization 2014)

sections.Blog:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, initial(s) OR Username Year, Title (in italics), blog, day and month of publication (if applicable), viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Notes and exceptions

  • If no full name is available, give the user name.
  • If no date is available, use n.d.

Example: in reference list

Smalls, S & Brook, S 2006, My great blog, blog, viewed 10 January 2008, <http://mygreatblog.blogspot.com>.

Example: in text

(Smalls & Brook 2010)
sections.Blog post:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, initial(s) OR Username Year, 'Title of post (in single quote marks)', Title of blog (in italics), blog post, day and month of publication (if applicable), viewed Date Month Year, &ltURL>.

Notes and exceptions

  • To reference an individual post within a whole blog, include the name of the whole blog and the date of the specific post.
  • If no full name is available, give the user name.
  • If no date is available, use n.d.

Example: in reference list

Bergmann, L 2011, ‘The active voice versus the passive voice’, blog post, Grammar Gang, 5 July, viewed 27 July 2011, <http://thegrammargang.blogspot. com.au/ 2011/07/
helpnest-feature-5-active- voice-versus.html>.

Example: in text

(Bergmann 2011)
sections.Facebook post:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, initial(s) OR Username Year, Title of post (in italics), Facebook, day and month of publication (if applicable), viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Notes and exceptions

  • For the title, use the first few words (up to 10) of the post.
  • If no full name is available, give the user name.
  • If no date is available, use n.d.

Example: in reference list

Smith, P 2015, Rethinking higher education the team is everything, Facebook, 25 April, viewed 16 June 2015, <https://www.facebook.com/pages/ Peter-P-Smith/196037770427320>.

Example: in text

(Smith 2015)
sections.Twitter:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, initial(s) OR Username Year, Title of post (in italics), Twitter, day and month of publication (if applicable), viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Notes and exceptions

  • For the title, use the first few words (up to 10) of the post.
  • If no full name is available, give the user name.
  • If no date is available, use n.d.

Example: in reference list

Obama, B 2016, It’s time for Senate leaders to put politics aside, Twitter, 17 May, viewed 19 May 2016, <https://twitter.com/BarackObama/status/
732589315478290432>.

Example: in text

(Obama 2016)

sections.Podcast:
Required information and layout

Author’s family name, Initial(s) OR Podcast title Year, Title of podcast (in italics), podcast, day and month of publication (if applicable), viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Notes and exceptions

  • If no author name is given, use the podcast title.
  • For the URL, give a link to the page where the podcast can be accessed.
  • If no date is available, use n.d.

Example: in reference list

Be The Serpent 2020, Episode 61: a time and a place, podcast, 20 May, viewed 21 May 2020, <https://betheserpent.podbean.com /e/episode-61-a-time-and-a-place />.

Example: in text

(Be The Serpent 2020)
sections.Radio programme:
Required information and layout

Programme title (in italics) Year, radio programme, Broadcaster, Place, Date Month.

Notes and exceptions

  • For name, use the programme title.
  • If no date is available, use n.d.

Example: in reference list

The search for meaning 1998, radio programme, ABC Radio, Sydney, 24 March.

Example: in text

(The search for meaning 1998)
sections.YouTube:
Required information and layout

Author name (Family names, Initial(s) OR Corporate name) Year, Title (in italics), YouTube, Date Month, viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Notes and exceptions

  • If no author (individual or corporate) is given, use the video title.

Example: in reference list

Bainbridge State College 2010, Plagiarism: how to avoid it, YouTube, 5 January, viewed June 5 2017, <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2q0NlWcTq1Y>.

Example: in text

(Bainbridge State College 2010)
sections.Television broadcast:
Required information and layout

Programme title (in italics) Year, television programme, Broadcaster, Place, Date Month.

Example: in reference list

Letters and numbers 2010, television programme, SBS Television, Melbourne, 6 October.

Example: in text

(Letters and numbers 2010)

For a specific episode from a television series:

Title of episode Year, television series episode, in Title of series (in italics), Publisher or broadcaster, Place of recording.

Notes and exceptions

  • Any special credits and other information that might be useful can be noted after the citation.

Example: in reference list

Once more with feeling 2001, television series episode, in Buffy the Vampire Slayer, UPN, United States. Written and directed by J. Whedon.

Example: in text

(Once more with feeling 2001)
sections.Video, film, DVD:
Required information and layout

Title (in italics) Year, video recording / motion picture / DVD, Producer, Place of publication.

Notes and exceptions

  • Add other useful information after the citation, e.g. Directed by [Name].

Example: reference list

Sunday too far away 1975, motion picture, South Australian Film Corporation, Adelaide. Directed by Ken Hannam.

Example: in text

(Sunday too far away 1975)

sections.Artwork:
Required information and layout

Artwork you have viewed in person

Artist's family name, Initial(s) Year, Title (in italics), item type, Place, viewed Date Month Year.

Example: reference list

Gaudernack, G 1907, Plique a jour, enamelled vase, Kunstindustrimuseet, Oslo, viewed 19 April 2010.

Example: in text

(Gaudernack 1907)

Artwork you have viewed online

Artist's family name, Initial(s) Year, Title (in italics), medium, Name of web site, place of web site if available, viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Example: in reference list

Hernandez, E 1982, Sun Mad, screenprint on paper, Smithsonian American Art Museum, viewed 1 February 2021, <https://americanart.si.edu/ exhibitions/chicano-graphics/online/ visual-connections/ ester-hernandez>

Example: in text

(Hernandez 1982)
sections.Picture or graph:
Required information and layout

Author's family name, Initial(s) Year, Title (in italics), viewed Date Month Year, <URL>

Example: in reference list

Willison, J & O'Regan, K 2006, Research skill development framework, viewed 14 December 2010, <http://www.adelaide.edu.au/clpd/ rsd/framework/>.

Example: in text

(Willison & O'Regan 2006)

sections.Dictionary:
Required information and layout

Title (in italics) Year, Xth edn, vol. #, Publisher, Place of publication.

Notes and exceptions

  • Only include in reference list if specific edition/publisher, etc. details are necessary.

Example: in reference list

Longman dictionary of contemporary English 2003, 3rd edn, Pearson Education Limited, Harlow, UK.

Example: in text

  • Include page number(s) where possible.

(Longman dictionary of contemporary English 2003, p. #)
sections.Encyclopedia entry:
Required information and layout

Author's family name, Initial(s) Year, Title (in italics), Xth edn, Publisher, Place of publication.

Example: in reference list

Crystal, D 1995, The Cambridge encyclopedia of the English language, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge.

Example: in text

  • Include page number(s) where possible.

(Crystal 1995, p. #)

Without an author:

Title (in italics) Year, Xth edn, vol. #, Publisher, Place of publication.

Example: in reference list

Encyclopaedia Britannica 1966, Encyclopaedia Britannica Inc., Chicago.

Example: in text

  • Include page number(s) where possible.

(Encyclopaedia Britannica 1966, p. #)
sections.Classics:
For classics (e.g. Virgil), give the line number and the date of the edition you have used in the reference list but not in the text.

Example: in reference list

Homer. The Odyssey , translated by H. Bettenson (Penguin Classics). Harmondsworth: Penguin Books. 1976.

 

Example: in text

(Homer Odyssey, 5.134-138) 
5 = book number
134-138 = line numbers

sections.Australian Bureau of Statistics:
Required information and layout

Australian Bureau of Statistics 2008, Title (in italics), catalog number if available (abbreviate to cat. no.), Publisher (abbreviate to ABS), viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Example: in reference list

Australian Bureau of Statistics 2008, Australian social trends 2007, cat. no. 4102.0, ABS, viewed 31 October 2008, <http://www.ausstats.abs.gov.au>.

Example: in text

(Australian Bureau of Statistics 2008)
sections.Emails, phone conversation, letters, int:
Required information and layout

(Author's family name, personal communication, Date Month Year.)

Notes and exceptions

  • It is preferable to include the details in the text only.

Example: in reference list

  • Treat as a personal communication; do not include it in the reference list.

Example: in text

A Polish learner’s dictionary was written in 2009 (Pius ten Hacken, personal communication, 5 November 2010).
sections.Lecture:
Required information and layout

Lecture notes given out during a lecture

Author's family name, Initial(s), Year, 'Title (in single quote marks)', lecture notes details, Institution Name, on Date Month Year (of lecture).

Example: in reference list

Cole, P 2010, 'Part 5: advanced electromagnetic theory', lecture notes distributed in the topic 7052 Electromagnetic theory and RFID applications, University of Adelaide, on 12 July 2010.

Example: in text

(Cole 2010)

Your own notes taken during a lecture

Notes and exceptions

  • It is preferable to include the details in the text only.

Example: in reference list

  • Treat as a personal communication; do not include it in the reference list.

Example: in text

During a lecture in the topic 7052 'Electromagnetic theory and RFID applications' given at the University of Adelaide on 12 July 2010, Professor Peter Cole said ...
sections.Map:
Required information and layout

Author's family name, Intial(s) Year, Title (in italics), scale if available, Publisher, Place of publication.

Example: in reference list

Mason, J 1832, Map of the countries lying between Spain and India,1:8,000,000, Ordnance Survey, London.

Example: in text

(Mason 1832)
sections.Patent:
Required information and layout

Author's family name, Intial(s) Year, Title (in italics), Patent details.

Example: in reference list

Hill, L 1956, Hills hoist, Australian Patent 215772.

Example: in text

(Hill 1956)
sections.PowerPoint:
Required information and layout

Author's family name, Initial(s) Year, 'Title (in single quote marks)', PowerPoint presentation, viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Example: in reference list

Aguilar, F 2001, 'Polyethylene biodigesters: production of biogas and organic fertilizer from animal manure', PowerPoint presentation, viewed 14 December 2010, <http://www.adelaide.edu.au/biogas/ poly_digester/>.

Example: in text

(Aguilar 2001)
sections.Report:
Required information and layout

For online reports, include date viewed and <URL>.

Author's family name, Initial(s) Year, Title (in italics), Publisher, Place of Publication.

Notes and exceptions

  • For online reports, include date viewed and <URL> (see "Reports by organisations without a specific author" example below).

Reference list

Bradley, D, Noonan, P, Nugent, H & Scales, B 2008, Review of Australian higher education, Australian Government, Canberra.

In text

(Bradley, Noonan & Scales 2008)

Reports by organisations without a specific author

Required information and layout

Report title (in italics) Year, Organisation, Publisher, Place of Publication (if available), viewed Date Month Year, <URL>.

Notes and exceptions

  • For online reports, include date viewed and <URL>.
  • If no publisher/place of publication is given, you can leave it out.

Example: in reference list

The least developed countries report 2010, United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, viewed 14 December 2010, <http://www.unctad.org/ Templates/webflyer.asp?docid=14129&intItemID=2068& lang=1>.

Example: in text

(The least developed countries report 2010)
sections.Thesis:
Required information and layout

Author's family name, Initial(s) Year, 'Title (in single quote marks)', thesis type, Institution Name, Place.

Notes and exceptions

  • If you viewed the thesis online, include DOI or other identifiers if available.

Example: in reference list

Ariyanto, S 1996, ‘An applied linguistic analysis of EFL teacher trainees' communicative competence in Jember, Indonesia’, MA thesis, University of Adelaide, Adelaide, http://hdl.handle.net/2440/108814. 

Example: in text

  • Page number(s) should be included where possible.
    Include page number(s) for all direct quotes.

(Ariyanto 1996, p. #)
